pages.text: Ptychodus comes from the Cretaceous, with fossils being found in formations across the world. It is a large ptychodontid, growing up to 10 m in length. Due to only being known from teeth material when first discovered sometime in the 1830s, Ptychodus was originally classified as either a batoid (Rays) or a hybodont (Shark-like fish).

This prevailed until 2016, when it was found that it was likely a selachii (True Shark), and in 2024 after the discovery of a complete body fossil, it was finally classified as a lamniforme (Mackerel Shark), ending nearly 200 years of uncertainty. The generic name derives from the Greek words 'ptychos', to mean 'fold'; and 'odon' to mean 'tooth'.
